question: Will the US, EU, or Brazil formally recognize Alexander Lukashenko as the President of Belarus before April 1, 2025?
description: A map of countries that do not recognize Lukashenko, current at the time of this question, is [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_reactions_to_the_2020_Belarusian_presidential_election_and_protests).
news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Georgia's 'President' Kavlashvili Congratulates Lukashenko on 'Re-election'**
Mikheil Kavlashvili, the self-proclaimed 'president' of Georgia, whose legitimacy is not recognized by the opposition, congratulated Alexander Lukashenko on his 're-election' as the president of Belarus. According to the Lukashenko administration, as reported by 'European Truth', Kavlashvili's congratulatory message stated that 'the mutual respect for sovereignty and territorial integrity is the most important foundation for cooperation and relations between nations.' Kavlashvili expressed hope that the Georgian-Belarusian relations will develop for the benefit of their countries and peoples. It is worth noting that the presidential 'elections' in Belarus took place on January 26, with Lukashenko 'winning' over 87% of the votes, with no independent OSCE observers present. The European Union, Australia, the UK, Canada, and New Zealand have already refused to recognize the January 26 'elections' as free and fair.
Original language: uk
Publish date: February 18, 2025 04:06 PM
Source:[eurointegration.com.ua](https://www.eurointegration.com.ua/news/2025/02/18/7205314/)

**Russian State Duma Approves Agreement on Security with Belarus**
The State Duma of the Russian Federation has approved the ratification of the agreement on guarantees of security between Russia and Belarus within the framework of the Union State. According to the press service of the State Duma, the document provides for mutual obligations to ensure security in case of threats to their sovereignty or territorial integrity. The agreement includes mutual assistance, including political, military, and other measures, in case of threats from third countries, international organizations, terrorist, or extremist groups. According to Vyacheslav Volodin, speaking on February 17, the ratification of the agreement is aimed at protecting the citizens and territory of the two states primarily from provocations by neighboring EU member states. One of the most significant components of the agreement is the possibility of deploying Russian tactical nuclear weapons on Belarusian territory. Russian Ambassador Boris Gryzlov stated that the agreement contributes to the formation of a unified defensive space on the external borders of the Union State. The agreement was signed in December 2024 by Russian President Vladimir Putin and Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko in Minsk. In February 2025, the document was submitted to parliament for ratification, with President Putin designating Deputy Foreign Minister Alexander Grushko as the official representative in the consideration of this issue.
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 18, 2025 12:45 PM
Source:[Ридус](https://www.ridus.ru/gosduma-odobrila-dogovor-o-bezopasnosti-s-belorussiej-566945.html)

**Lukashenko Assures Haftar of Belarus' Support**
Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko welcomed Libyan Field Marshal Khalifa Haftar to the Palace of Independence on February 18, 2025. Lukashenko said, 'Please consider yourself as being among friends, at home. I have read a lot about you, heard a lot, and been told a lot about you. Unfortunately, I am meeting you for the first time. I want you to know that we are well-informed about the situation in Libya. We know Libya well. I have a special relationship with your people. I have visited Libya before. Of course, today it's a different Libya. But you should know that we are ready to do everything that you see as useful in Belarus. Everything we agree on today, during your stay in Belarus, we will implement on time. So, please allow me to welcome you to Belarus and your accompanying delegation, members of the delegation. We are ready to work.' 
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 18, 2025 08:59 AM
Source:[Беларусь Сегодня](https://www.sb.by/articles/lukashenko-glavnokomanduyushchemu-liviyskoy-natsionalnoy-armiey-khaftaru-vse-o-chem-dogovorimsya-my-.html)

**Russia and US Begin Peace Talks: What's Next for Europe?**
Belarusian President Lukashenko has stated that developing a comfortable business environment is a priority for the country's economic policy. In 2024, real disposable income in Belarus increased by 9.7%. Meanwhile, China has called for deeper cooperation within the BRICS partnership after US President Trump's threats. The upcoming negotiations between Russia and the US have sparked questions about what to expect and whether Europe will be left out of major global events.

**Lukashenko to Meet with Libyan National Army Commander**
Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko will meet with the Commander-in-Chief of the Libyan National Army, Field Marshal Khalifa Belqasim Haftar, on February 18 to discuss cooperation between the two countries in humanitarian and social spheres, as well as economic cooperation. The meeting is taking place at the Palace of Independence in Minsk, Belarus. According to the Belarusian news agency Belta, the talks will focus on areas where Belarus and Libya can work together. No further details have been released about the meeting. 'The meeting will be an opportunity for Belarus and Libya to discuss ways to strengthen their cooperation in various fields,' said a spokesperson for the Belarusian government. 'We are looking forward to a productive conversation and exploring new areas of cooperation.' 
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 18, 2025 08:27 AM
Source:[Рамблер](https://news.rambler.ru/world/54221357-lukashenko-provodit-vstrechu-s-glavoy-liviyskoy-natsionalnoy-armii/)

**Lukashenko's Plan to Restrict Business Money Transfers**
Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko has announced plans to restrict the ability of businesses to transfer money abroad. Lukashenko stated, 'If you want to buy something abroad, let's work out a system so that no one attaches themselves to you. But if you hide your money earned here abroad, what should my attitude towards you be?' The move is seen as a logical step, as the government has already taken significant amounts from foreign investors. In 2022, the government restricted the right of investors from unfriendly countries to manage their property, and in 2023, they prohibited them from transferring profits and dividends abroad. However, despite these measures, direct foreign investment in Belarus decreased to $5.2 billion in 2024, down from $5.8 billion in the previous year. Lukashenko has expressed frustration with the quality of investments, particularly from Russia, and has accused foreign investors of taking money out of the country rather than investing it. He has promised to provide 'the most severe support' to businesses, but has not specified how he plans to do so.
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 18, 2025 05:39 AM
Source:[Хартия 97](https://charter97.org/be/news/2025/2/18/630244/)

**Belarusian President Emphasizes Need for Self-Regulating Price System**
Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko emphasized the need for a self-regulating system of price formation, which would not stifle business and production. He stated, 'Let the producer sell, but he must remember that he produced it, and the people who are nearby, they buy it. And they must have the opportunity to buy this product.' The President also noted that prices should not fluctuate, especially upwards, and that the Ministry of Antimonopoly Regulation and Trade should work towards reducing complaints about prices. According to the Minister of Antimonopoly Regulation and Trade, Arthur Karpyovich, the goal is to have fewer complaints about prices, and the trend in recent years has been towards a decrease in complaints. The head of the analytical department of the Ministry of Antimonopoly Regulation and Trade, Irina Ivanovskaya, reported that the inflation rate for 2024 was 5.2%, which is one of the lowest in the Eurasian Economic Union. In January 2025, the inflation rate remained at 5.2%. The Committee for State Control reported that there were instances of price manipulation in three stores in the Kaliakinsk, Narovlyansky, and Petrikovsky districts, where prices for vegetables and fruits were higher than the allowed maximum. However, it was noted that such cases are rare, and most private stores in the country operate fairly. The head of the main department of trade and services of the Gomel Oblast Executive Committee, Alexander Kachan, stated that the sale of products is under control, and the demand for stable food products remains high. Residents of rural areas, such as Galiya Parazhinskaya from the village of Batevichi, prefer to shop at cooperative stores, where they can buy fresh produce and other essential goods at reasonable prices.
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 18, 2025 05:08 AM
Source:[Беларусь Сегодня](https://www.sb.by/articles/ne-vyshe-predelnoy.html)

**President Orders Decriminalization of Economic Risks**
Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko has instructed to decriminalize economic risks. He stated that the country needs to focus on this issue, as there are unscrupulous business entities and isolated cases that cast a shadow of distrust on the entire business community. Lukashenko emphasized that the government will not create artificial barriers due to a few scammers, but will approach the issue with pragmatism and common sense. He added that decisions should be made in the interests of the economy. According to Lukashenko, the government and private sectors, as well as foreign companies, should work for the common good of the people and the country. Business representatives, including those interviewed by 'ЭГ', have repeatedly pointed out the importance of decriminalizing tax offenses, citing the example of Russia, where a law was passed in 2023 to automatically dismiss a criminal case if the tax debt, penalties, and fines are fully paid. In Belarus, however, a person must not only pay the fine, penalties, and tax debt, but also a criminal-law compensation equal to the amount of the debt, which is often impossible to do. Therefore, Belarusian business unions are advocating for a review of approaches to punishing tax offenses, taking into account Russian practice.
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 17, 2025 09:00 PM
Source:[neg.by](https://neg.by/novosti/otkrytj/prezident-poruchil-provesti-dekriminalizatsiyu-ekonomicheskikh-riskov/)

**Lukashenko Promises to Support Honest Business Owners**
Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko has promised to 'harshly support' private business owners who 'honestly work' for the benefit of Belarus. Lukashenko vowed to provide equal conditions for all business representatives, regardless of ownership form, 'who honestly work for the state, for the people, by law, and pay taxes.' He emphasized that the private sector will be supported, but only if they are 'clean and transparent, like glass.' Lukashenko assured that if this condition is met, 'no one will take away your business, no one will lean on you, and no one will divide anything.' He cited the example of the Russian e-commerce platform Wildberries, which he said the Belarusian government is willing to support, as long as it helps fill the domestic market with local products and does not lead to monopolization and closure of small shops. 'Any enterprise must work for Belarus, for the state. Then I will have no complaints about you,' Lukashenko said.
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 17, 2025 11:21 AM
Source:[telegraf.news](https://telegraf.news/ehkonomika/skazhite-kto-meshaet-golova-sletit-s-ljubogo-lukashenko-poobeshhal-zhestoko-podderzhivat-etih-biznesmenov/)

**Lukashenko Demands Equal Treatment for Private and State-Owned Enterprises**
Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko held a meeting with representatives of private Belarusian enterprises on February 17 and demanded that private and state-owned enterprises be put on an equal footing. Lukashenko emphasized that there are no 'non-state' people in Belarus, only private and state-owned enterprises. He called on both business and officials to 'act exclusively in the interests of the economy.' Lukashenko stated that the government is just as interested as entrepreneurs in seeing the private and state sectors, as well as foreign enterprises, 'work for the common good of people and the country.' He emphasized the need to 'put private and state-owned forms of enterprise ownership on an equal footing.' Lukashenko also highlighted the need to 'decriminalize economic risks' and warned that the actions of a few 'unscrupulous individuals' should not create artificial barriers for the business community. 'We will not build artificial barriers due to a few scammers,' Lukashenko said. 'We need to approach everything with pragmatism and common sense.'
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 17, 2025 09:24 AM
Source:[telegraf.news](https://telegraf.news/ehkonomika/nikakih-barerov-iz-za-neskolkih-zhulikov-lukashenko-potreboval-postavit-chastnye-i-gospredpriyatiya-v-ravnye-usloviya/)

**Lukashenko dismisses EU criticism, says election recognition is 'absolutely irrelevant'**
Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko cast his vote in the presidential election on Sunday in Minsk, accompanied by his white dog Umka. When asked by journalists who he voted for, Lukashenko replied, 'I must be honest: I voted for all!' He also stated that he is in dialogue with his opponents, whom he referred to as the opposition. Lukashenko dismissed the EU's sharp criticism of the election process and showed no concern about the EU's announcement that it will not recognize the election. He said, 'It will have no impact on us whether the European Union recognizes our election or not. Believe me, it's absolutely irrelevant to me whether you recognize our election or not. What's important to me is that the Belarusians recognize this election and that it ends as peacefully as it began.' The EU Parliament had previously condemned the election as a sham on January 22, calling on EU member states and the international community not to recognize Lukashenko's legitimacy as president after January 26, 2025. Lukashenko dismissed this criticism, saying that it's impossible to evaluate something that has not yet happened. He also stated that the value of the EU Parliament's statement is zero. The early voting for the presidential election in Belarus began on January 21, and five candidates are running for the highest office in the country: Oleg Gaidukewitsch, Anna Kanopazkaja, Sergei Syrankow, Alexander Chischnjak, and Lukashenko himself. The election is taking place from 8 to 20 local time, with over 5,000 polling stations open across the country. For the first time in Belarus' history, there are no polling stations abroad due to security reasons and a lack of personnel in diplomatic missions. Approximately 6.9 million citizens are eligible to vote, and the election is considered complete if more than half of the voters cast their ballots.
Original language: de
Publish date: January 26, 2025 02:51 PM
Source:[rt.com](https://de.rt.com/europa/234422-lukaschenko-zu-eu-es-ist/)

**Lukashenko Responds to Question About Searching for a Successor**
Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko stated that he is not currently searching for a successor to transfer power, according to BelTA. 'I am not looking for this successor... We are living through these elections now. After the elections, we will think about it,' he said. Lukashenko emphasized the need to focus on successfully navigating the 2025 year and building the country's future by developing cooperation with Russia and avoiding dependence on Western countries. Belarus is currently holding presidential elections, with voting taking place on January 26. The election is being held without the presence of Western observers, and the Belarusian authorities have not opened polling stations abroad due to 'security concerns' and a reduction in the Belarusian diplomatic corps in some countries. The election features five candidates, including incumbent President Lukashenko, Oleg Gaidukevich, a deputy of the House of Representatives and leader of the Liberal-Democratic Party, Anna Kanopatskaya, a businessman and former deputy of the House of Representatives, Sergey Syranek, the first secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party, and Alexander Khizhnyak, the chairman of the Republican Party of Labor and Justice. Two of the candidates, Gaidukevich and Syranek, have already acknowledged Lukashenko's victory. The European Parliament has released a resolution calling on EU countries and the international community not to recognize the legitimacy of Lukashenko's victory. Lukashenko responded by stating that he does not care about the EU's refusal to recognize the election results.
Original language: ru
Publish date: January 26, 2025 02:49 PM
Source:[РБК](https://www.rbc.ru/rbcfreenews/679644f99a7947dbc56c932e)

**Self-proclaimed president of Belarus: I don't care if EU recognises our elections**
Belarusian self-proclaimed president Alexander Lukashenko stated that he does not care if the West recognizes the presidential 'elections' taking place on January 26. Lukashenko said, 'Whether the European Union recognises these elections or not is a matter of taste. Believe me, I assure you, I don't care whether you recognise our elections or not.' He added that if the West recognizes the elections, 'we will respond, we will thank them.' Lukashenko also compared the situation to other countries, saying, 'If I were to make a statement now that I do not recognise the US election and do not recognise Trump, would anything change in America? Or in the UK: if I don't recognise Starmer, what will happen in the UK? Nothing. Similarly, nothing will happen here,' the Belarusian leader said.

Publish date: January 26, 2025 11:51 AM
Source:[Українська правда](https://www.pravda.com.ua/eng/news/2025/01/26/7495322/)

**Lukashenko: EU Recognition of Belarus Elections Unimportant**
Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko stated that the European Union's decision to recognize or not recognize the legitimacy of the presidential elections in Belarus will not affect the country. Lukashenko said, 'It's a matter of taste, whether you recognize these elections or not. I don't care, I'm fine either way. What's important to me is that the Belarusians recognize these elections and that they end peacefully, just like they started.' The presidential elections in Belarus began on January 26, 2025, with a voter turnout of 56.64% by 12:00. Lukashenko, who is running for his seventh term, has already cast his vote.

**Lukashenko dismisses EU's potential refusal to recognize election results**
Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko stated that the European Union's decision not to recognize the results of the presidential election is of no significance to him. 'It doesn't matter to us. Whether they recognize these elections or not in the European Union, that's their business. Believe me, it's absolutely 'фиолетово' (a Russian idiom meaning 'of no importance') to me,' Lukashenko said. Lukashenko previously stated that Belarus will not experience the same level of unrest that occurred after the 2020 presidential election.

**Lukashenko: EU's Recognition of Election Unimportant to Him**
Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko stated that it is 'unimportant' to him whether the European Union recognizes the presidential election in the country or not, calling it 'a matter of taste'. Lukashenko emphasized that the main thing for him is that Belarusians recognize the election and that it ends peacefully. He questioned what the EU would do if the US made a statement or remained silent about the election. Commenting on the European Parliament's resolution, which called for not recognizing Lukashenko's 'expected victory', the president called it 'a groveling before the older brothers in Washington'. Lukashenko asked how it is possible to evaluate something that has not yet occurred and urged to consider the resolution as a given fact. He also noted that the EU's statement did not harm Belarus, but rather was beneficial to it. The presidential election in Belarus is scheduled for January 26. Four other candidates are running against Lukashenko: Oleg Gaidukevich, Anna Kanopatskaya, Sergei Syarankou, and Alexander Khizhnyak. Two of the candidates, Gaidukevich and Syarankou, have already recognized Lukashenko's victory before the election. If Lukashenko wins, it will be his seventh presidential term, as he has been in office since 1994 and is the first and currently the only president of Belarus. His victory in the 2020 election was not recognized by the opposition, the EU, and the US, leading to mass protests in the country that lasted for several months.

Publish date: January 26, 2025 10:04 AM

**Lukashenko: European Parliament's Resolution on Belarus Elections is 'Groveling Before the US'**
Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko has called the European Parliament's (EP) resolution on non-recognition of the country's elections 'a groveling before the US'. He stated, 'This is a groveling before the 'older brothers' in Washington.' The EP resolution, signed on January 21, aims to not recognize the Belarusian presidential election and expand sanctions against the country, citing the illegitimacy of the election. Belarusian Foreign Minister Anatoly Glaz responded that the EU's non-recognition of the election results would be seen as direct interference in the country's internal affairs. He also noted that 330 foreign journalists have been invited to cover the election. Lukashenko previously stated that the country would not experience the same level of unrest and protests as in 2020.

**Lukashenko: Belarus Will Not Be Affected by Western Recognition of Election Results**
Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko stated that the country will not be affected if Western countries do not recognize the presidential election results. 'Nothing will happen to us. You in the European Union recognize or do not recognize these elections... It's a matter of taste. Believe me, it's absolutely, as you say, 'it's purple to me', - Lukashenko said in a conversation with journalists. He is confident that the West will not recognize the election results, but the people will, which is the most important thing. The presidential election in Belarus has already seen early voting, with the main voting day taking place on January 26. The election results will be announced no later than February 5, 2025.

**Lukashenko Advises EU to Negotiate with Russia**
Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko advised the European Union to negotiate and cooperate with Russia, citing Russia's ability to provide Europe with resources. Lukashenko stated, 'There is a lack of spirit in the EU to take this step.' Lukashenko also emphasized that Belarus is holding elections for its own people, regardless of whether others like it or not. The European Parliament previously passed a resolution urging not to recognize the results of the upcoming presidential elections in Belarus, with 567 deputies in support, 25 against, and 66 abstaining. The elections are scheduled to take place on January 26, 2025, with over 5,000 polling stations set up across the country, including in hospitals, sanatoriums, and rest homes. The West has been criticized for irritating Belarus' sovereignty, according to the Federation Council.

**European Parliament Declares Belarus Elections a 'Fiction', Urges EU Not to Recognize Lukashenko**
The European Parliament has called on the EU not to recognize Alexander Lukashenko as the legitimate president of Belarus, citing the upcoming presidential elections as 'a fiction'. The parliamentarians stated that the elections, scheduled for January 26, are a sham, and that there are only 'formal' candidates challenging Lukashenko's rule. They also condemned the long-standing and severe human rights abuses and democratic principles violations in Belarus, and urged the EU, its member states, and the international community not to recognize Lukashenko's legitimacy as president. The European Parliament expressed its unwavering support for the Belarusian people in their pursuit of democracy, freedom, and human rights. 'In contrast to 2020, there are only formal 'candidates' who will challenge him in the elections this month. Confirming its non-recognition of Mr. Lukashenko as President and its position that the entire Belarusian regime is illegitimate, MEPs express their unshakeable support for the Belarusian people in their quest for democracy, freedom and human rights,' the parliamentarians said.
Original language: ru
Publish date: January 22, 2025 04:57 PM
Source:[OBOZREVATEL](https://www.obozrevatel.com/belarus/ne-vyiboryi-a-fiktsiya-evroparlament-prizval-ne-priznavat-lukashenko-legitimnyim-prezidentom-belarusi.htm)

**European Parliament Rejects Upcoming Belarus Presidential Election**
The European Parliament has drafted a resolution calling on EU countries not to recognize the results of the presidential election in Belarus, scheduled for January 26. The resolution states that the upcoming election and pre-election campaign are 'fake' and do not meet international democratic election standards. The European Parliament also urges the EU, its member states, and the international community to reject the legitimacy of Alexander Lukashenko as president after January 26, 2025, and to hold 'free and fair elections in Belarus.' Additionally, the European Parliament calls for increased sanctions against individuals and organizations responsible for repression in Belarus and Russia's aggression against Ukraine. 'The European Parliament condemns the lack of freedom, justice, and transparency ahead of the so-called presidential elections in Belarus and calls on the EU, its member states, and the international community to categorically reject the upcoming elections and pre-election campaign as fictitious, as they do not meet the minimum international standards for democratic elections,' the document reads.
Original language: ru
Publish date: January 22, 2025 02:01 PM
Source:[bdg.by](https://bdg.news/news/politics/evroparlament-ne-nameren-priznavat-itogi-vyborov-v-belarusi)

**European Parliament Urges EU Not to Recognize Belarus Presidential Election Results**
The European Parliament has adopted a resolution calling on the EU and its member states not to recognize the results of the upcoming presidential elections in Belarus. The document was supported by 567 deputies, with 25 opposing and 66 abstaining. The resolution states, 'The Parliament asks the EU, its member states, and the international community not to recognize the legitimacy of the current dictator Alexander Lukashenko as president after the vote.' The elections are scheduled for January 26, 2025, and will feature voting stations equipped with panic buttons and video surveillance. Belarusian Central Election Commission head Igor Karpenko responded to former US Secretary of State Antony Blinken's criticism of the elections, saying, 'The US has put on a crown for itself by criticizing our elections.'
Original language: ru
Publish date: January 22, 2025 12:50 PM
Source:[Рамблер](https://news.rambler.ru/world/54080855-ep-prizval-strany-evrosoyuza-ne-priznavat-itogi-vyborov-v-belorussii/)

**European Parliament to Urge EU Not to Recognize Belarus Presidential Election Results**
The European Parliament plans to urge the European Union not to recognize the results of the presidential election in Belarus. According to a draft document, the parliament 'calls on the EU, its member states, and the international community to continue not to recognize the legitimacy of Alexander Lukashenko as President after January 26, 2025.' The European Parliament also calls for free and fair elections in the country. A vote on the anti-Belarusian resolution is scheduled for Wednesday, January 22.

**European Parliament to Urge EU Not to Recognize Belarus Presidential Election Results**
The European Parliament plans to urge the European Union not to recognize the results of the presidential election in Belarus. According to a draft document, the European Parliament 'calls on the EU, its member states, and the international community to continue not to recognize the legitimacy of Alexander Lukashenko as President of Belarus after January 26, 2025.' The European Parliament also calls for free and fair elections in the country. A vote on the anti-Belarusian resolution is scheduled for Wednesday, January 22. forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, the United States, the European Union, and Brazil have been cautious in recognizing leaders who have come to power through disputed elections or undemocratic means. After the 2020 Belarusian presidential election, most Western countries, including the US and the EU, refused to recognize Alexander Lukashenko as the legitimate president due to alleged election fraud. Brazil's reaction was less pronounced, but it also did not move to formally recognize Lukashenko amid international criticism. This indicates a low base rate for formal recognition of disputed leaders shortly after contested elections. Therefore, based on historical precedent, the initial estimated probability of the US, EU, or Brazil formally recognizing Lukashenko by April 1, 2025, is set at 20%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current Political Relations
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Neither the US nor the EU has indicated any significant shift in policy towards recognizing Lukashenko as legitimate, due to ongoing tensions and disagreements surrounding human rights abuses and democratic principles in Belarus. Brazil's Government, despite generally adopting a more neutral stance, has not taken any diplomatic steps toward recognition either.

perspective_derived_factors.name: International Pressure
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: There continues to be substantial international pressure, especially from Western countries, to promote democratic norms and reject illegitimate governmental transitions. Additionally, sanctions and diplomatic isolation imposed by the US and EU make it unlikely they would reverse their stance absent substantial political reforms in Belarus.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Belarusian Domestic Stability
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Despite Lukashenko's hold on power, the domestic opposition within Belarus remains active, and any international recognition would likely provoke domestic unrest. This factor discourages formal recognition from risk-averse governments, contributing to the unlikeliness of a shift.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The European Union, along with other Western countries like the UK, Australia, Canada, and New Zealand, has refused to recognize the January 26 elections in Belarus as free and fair. The European Parliament has adopted a resolution calling on EU member states not to recognize Lukashenko's presidency.
